Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
cc3d - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Help.Tip: Maximum static to solve for (in milliseconds).
Help.Text:
cc3d - MAX_STATIC
Maximum static to solve for (in milliseconds).
 
 Default =  40.0
 Allowed =  real > 0.

Help.Tip: Maximum fold in a CMP.
Help.Text:
cc3d - FOLD_MAX
Maximum fold in a CMP.
 
 Default =  50
 Allowed =  int > 0.
 
 Used to set up the trace buffer indexing of bins on disk.
 If the fold of an input CMP exceeds FOLD_MAX the excess traces are dropped.

Help.Tip: Weight for static estimate from stacked correlations.
Help.Text:
cc3d - WEIGHT
Weight for static estimate from stacked correlations.
 
 Default =  0.5
 Allowed = real from 0.0 through 1.0
 
 WEIGHT = 1.0 uses only picks of stacked correlations (like FISH).
 WEIGHT = 0.0 uses only the average pick of individual correlations (like IMS).
 WEIGHT = 0.5 uses an average of the two types of picks.

Help.Tip: Number of solution iterations (passes).
Help.Text:
cc3d - NUM_ITER
Number of solution iterations (passes).
 
 Default =  20
 Allowed =  int >= 1.

Help.Tip: Offset bin interval (in distance) for estimating residual NMO.
Help.Text:
cc3d - OFF_WID
Offset bin interval (in distance) for estimating residual NMO.
 
 Default =  1000
 Allowed =  real > 0.
 
 OFF_WID determines the number of offsets in the least-squares fit of time
 shifts versus offset squared.  OFF_WID is used only if TERMS = 4.

Help.Tip: Method to use in static solution.
Help.Text:
cc3d - TERMS
Method to use in static solution.
 
 Default =  3
 Allowed =  1,2,3,4
 
 TERMS = 1 does source and/or receiver solution only.  It uses in the full
           stack only those traces with same ground position as the partial
           stack (FISH-style).
 
 TERMS = 2 does source and/or receiver solution only.  It uses in the full
           stack all the super-CMP traces (original CC3D-style).
 
 TERMS = 3 is the same as TERMS = 2, but also uses CMP term.
 
 TERMS = 4 is the same as TERMS = 2, but also uses CMP term and residual NMO
           (offset) term.
 
 (TERMS = 1 or 3 are recommended based on very little experience.)
 (Generally TERMS = 1 is expected to work better than TERMS = 2.)

Help.Tip: Power for weighting the residual static shifts.
Help.Text:
cc3d - PWR_CC
Power for weighting the residual static shifts.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed =  real >= 0.0
 
 Residual static shifts are weighted by correlation coefficients raised
 to this power.  This allows picks from poor correlations to be weighted less
 than picks from good correlations.
 
 This parameter is not in the user interface because it has not been
 determined whether it is advisable to adjust it.

Help.Tip: Taper for correlation functions.
Help.Text:
cc3d - TAPER
Taper for correlation functions.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed =  real between 0.0 (no taper) and 1.0 (full taper).
 
 Correlation functions are tapered down by this fraction at the edges.
 The calculated taper is symmetric and linear.
 The center of the taper always has value 1.0.
 The ends of the taper have value (1.0 - TAPER).
 If TAPER is 0.0, the correlation will not be tapered (all values 1.0).
 If TAPER is 0.5, the correlation will be tapered down to 0.5 at the ends.
 If TAPER is 1.0, the correlation will be tapered down to 0.0 at the ends.
 
 This parameter is not in the user interface because it has not been
 determined whether it is advisable to adjust it.

Help.Tip: Static values are updated by this fraction after each pass.
Help.Text:
cc3d - UPDATE
Static values are updated by this fraction after each pass.
 
 Default =  0.8
 Allowed =  real between 0.0 and 1.0
 
 This parameter is not in the user interface because it has not been
 determined whether it is advisable to adjust it.

Help.Tip: Choose PATH_SRC using a file selection dialog box.
Help.Text:
cc3d - SELECT_PATH_SRC
Choose PATH_SRC using a file selection dialog box.

Help.Tip: Name for the output source static file.
Help.Text:
cc3d - PATH_SRC
Name for the output source static file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 If PATH_SRC = NONE, then do not calculate or output source statics.
 
 At least one static file (PATH_SRC or PATH_REC) must be specified.
 
 The extension .cc3d will always be appended.
 
 Files are saved after each iteration, overwriting the previous contents of
 the file.  The iteration count will be included in the file history cards.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_SRC.
Help.Text:
cc3d - PATH_SRC_INFO
Status of PATH_SRC.

Help.Tip: Choose PATH_REC using a file selection dialog box.
Help.Text:
cc3d - SELECT_PATH_REC
Choose PATH_REC using a file selection dialog box.

Help.Tip: Name for the output receiver static file.
Help.Text:
cc3d - PATH_REC
Name for the output receiver static file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 If PATH_REC = NONE, then do not calculate or output receiver statics.
 
 At least one static file (PATH_SRC or PATH_REC) must be specified.
 
 The extension .cc3d will always be appended.
 
 Files are saved after each iteration, overwriting the previous contents of
 the file.  The iteration count will be included in the file history cards.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_REC.
Help.Text:
cc3d - PATH_REC_INFO
Status of PATH_REC.

Help.Tip: Type of static correlation files to save.
Help.Text:
cc3d - CORR_FILES
Type of static correlation files to save.
 
 Default = TRC8
 Allowed = TRC8 (save TRCIO byte files with the extension .trc8)
 Allowed = NONE (do not save correlation files)
 
 The names of the static correlation files will be the same as PATH_SRC and
 PATH_REC except for the extension.
 
 Files are saved after each iteration, overwriting the previous contents
 of the file.
 
 A CBYT option allows the correlation files to be plotted and edited easily.
 This option automatically updates the statics files based on correlation
 edits.
 
 CORR_FILES is always forced to NONE for parallel processing (more than 1 CPU).

Help.Tip: Whether to omit dead traces from the output correlation files.
Help.Text:
cc3d - NO_DEAD
Whether to omit dead traces from the output correlation files.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO
 
 Setting NO_DEAD = YES may be desirable if the correlation files are very
 large and consist mostly of dead traces.

Help.Tip: How much printing to do.
Help.Text:
cc3d - OPT_PRINT
How much printing to do.
 
 Default =  MIN
 Allowed =  MIN (do a minimum amount of printing).
 Allowed =  MAX (print complete table of the calculated static values).

Help.Tip: Whether to stop before outputting any traces.
Help.Text:
cc3d - DEAD_END
Whether to stop before outputting any traces.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES/NO
 
 If this parameter is YES, this will be a dead-end process which does not
 output any traces.
 
 If this parameter is NO, all input traces will be shifted and output, in
 the same order they were received.
 
 Static files and correlation files will always be written, regardless of the
 value of DEAD_END.
 
 Stopping before outputting any traces reduces the required temporary disk
 space by a factor of at least 5, and more commonly by about 10 on average.
 The disk savings are more significant when trace correlation windows are
 small.
 
 DEAD_END is always forced to YES for parallel processing (more than 1 CPU).

Help.Tip: Header word(s) to use to identify source locations.
Help.Text:
cc3d - HDR_SRC
Header word(s) to use to identify source locations.
 
 Default = SEQU
 Allowed = SEQU  (source sequential ground position - header word  46)
 Allowed = GROUP (original source group number      - header word   9)
 Allowed = LNSP  (source shotpoint and line number  - header words 29 and 26)
 Allowed = GRID  (source grid coordinates           - header words 33 and 34)
 
 SEQU coordinates:
  Normally, if sequential ground position header words have been set in the
  input dataset, the sequential ground position is a good choice for source
  and receiver coordinates in 2D and 3D surveys.
 
 GROUP coordinates:
  The original source group number should generally be used for 2D and 3D
  surveys if a source occupies the same location more than once.
 
 LNSP coordinates:
  Line number and shotpoint header words are generally good choices in 3D
  surveys.
 
 GRID coordinates:
  Grid coordinates are less desirable than line number and shotpoint for
  the following reasons:
   1. Grid coordinates may not be densely populated, making internal
       calculations slower, disk use higher, and static and correlation
       files much larger.
   2. Statics are calculated only at regular grid intersections.  If
       sources and receivers are not always located exactly on the
       intersections then applying the statics files will probably produce
       somewhat inaccurate results.

Help.Tip: First header word to use for designating source locations.
Help.Text:
cc3d - HDR_SX
First header word to use for designating source locations.
 
 Default = 46
 Allowed = 46  (source sequential ground position - header word  46)
 Allowed = 9   (original source group number      - header word   9)
 Allowed = 29  (source shotpoint and line number  - header words 29 and 26)
 Allowed = 33  (source grid coordinates           - header words 33 and 34)

Help.Tip: Minimum value of HDR_SX.
Help.Text:
cc3d - SX_INIT
Minimum value of HDR_SX.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real (in units of header word HDR_SX).

Help.Tip: Increment between values of HDR_SX.
Help.Text:
cc3d - SX_INC
Increment between values of HDR_SX.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 Increment between values of HDR_SX for occupied source locations.

Help.Tip: Maximum value of HDR_SX.
Help.Text:
cc3d - SX_LAST
Maximum value of HDR_SX.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 If both SX_LAST and SX_TOT are specified, SX_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Total number of HDR_SX values.
Help.Text:
cc3d - SX_TOT
Total number of HDR_SX values.
 
 Default =  1
 Allowed = int > 0
 
 If both SX_LAST and SX_TOT are specified, SX_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Second header word to use for designating source locations.
Help.Text:
cc3d - HDR_SY
Second header word to use for designating source locations.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = 0   (source sequential ground position - header word  46)
 Allowed = 0   (original source group number      - header word   9)
 Allowed = 26  (source shotpoint and line number  - header words 29 and 26)
 Allowed = 34  (source grid coordinates           - header words 33 and 34)

Help.Tip: Minimum value of header word 34.
Help.Text:
cc3d - SY_INIT
Minimum value of header word 34.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Increment between values of header word 34.
Help.Text:
cc3d - SY_INC
Increment between values of header word 34.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Increment between values of header word 34 for occupied source locations.

Help.Tip: Maximum value of header word 34.
Help.Text:
cc3d - SY_LAST
Maximum value of header word 34.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 If both SY_LAST and SY_TOT are specified, SY_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Total number of header word 34 values.
Help.Text:
cc3d - SY_TOT
Total number of header word 34 values.
 
 Default =  1
 Allowed = int > 0
 
 If both SY_LAST and SY_TOT are specified, SY_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Header word(s) to use to identify receiver locations.
Help.Text:
cc3d - HDR_REC
Header word(s) to use to identify receiver locations.
 
 Default = SEQU
 Allowed = SEQU  (receiver sequential ground position - header word  47)
 Allowed = LNSP  (receiver shotpoint and line number  - header words 28 and 27)
 Allowed = GRID  (receiver grid coordinates           - header words 35 and 36)
 
 SEQU coordinates:
  Normally, if sequential ground position header words have been set in the
  input dataset, the sequential ground position is a good choice for source
  and receiver coordinates in 2D and 3D surveys.
 
 LNSP coordinates:
  Line number and shotpoint header words are generally good choices in 3D
  surveys.
 
 GRID coordinates:
  Grid coordinates are less desirable than line number and shotpoint for
  the following reasons:
   1. Grid coordinates may not be densely populated, making internal
       calculations slower, disk use higher, and static and correlation
       files much larger.
   2. Statics are calculated only at regular grid intersections.  If
       sources and receivers are not always located exactly on the
       intersections then applying the statics files will probably produce
       somewhat inaccurate results.

Help.Tip: First header word to use for designating receiver locations.
Help.Text:
cc3d - HDR_RX
First header word to use for designating receiver locations.
 
 Default = 47
 Allowed = 47  (receiver sequential ground position - header word  47)
 Allowed = 28  (receiver shotpoint and line number  - header words 28 and 27)
 Allowed = 35  (receiver grid coordinates           - header words 35 and 36)

Help.Tip: Minimum value of HDR_RX.
Help.Text:
cc3d - RX_INIT
Minimum value of HDR_RX.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real (in units of header word HDR_RX).

Help.Tip: Increment between values of HDR_RX.
Help.Text:
cc3d - RX_INC
Increment between values of HDR_RX.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 Increment between values of HDR_RX for occupied receiver locations.

Help.Tip: Maximum value of HDR_RX.
Help.Text:
cc3d - RX_LAST
Maximum value of HDR_RX.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 If both RX_LAST and RX_TOT are specified, RX_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Total number of HDR_RX values.
Help.Text:
cc3d - RX_TOT
Total number of HDR_RX values.
 
 Default =  1
 Allowed = int > 0
 
 If both RX_LAST and RX_TOT are specified, RX_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Second header word to use for designating receiver locations.
Help.Text:
cc3d - HDR_RY
Second header word to use for designating receiver locations.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = 0   (receiver sequential ground position - header word  47)
 Allowed = 27  (receiver shotpoint and line number  - header words 28 and 27)
 Allowed = 36  (receiver grid coordinates           - header words 35 and 36)

Help.Tip: Minimum value of header word 36.
Help.Text:
cc3d - RY_INIT
Minimum value of header word 36.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Increment between values of header word 36.
Help.Text:
cc3d - RY_INC
Increment between values of header word 36.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 Increment between values of header word 36 for occupied receiver locations.

Help.Tip: Maximum value of header word 36.
Help.Text:
cc3d - RY_LAST
Maximum value of header word 36.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 If both RY_LAST and RY_TOT are specified, RY_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Total number of header word 36 values.
Help.Text:
cc3d - RY_TOT
Total number of header word 36 values.
 
 Default =  1
 Allowed = int > 0
 
 If both RY_LAST and RY_TOT are specified, RY_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Number of CMPs to composite in the CMP X grid direction.
Help.Text:
cc3d - COMP_X
Number of CMPs to composite in the CMP X grid direction.
 
 Default = 5
 Allowed = int > 0
 
 Number of CMPs to composite in the CMP X grid direction to form super-CMP
 base traces.

Help.Tip: Minimum CMP X grid location (header word 7).
Help.Text:
cc3d - CMPX_INIT
Minimum CMP X grid location (header word 7).
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Increment between header word 7 values for CMP locations.
Help.Text:
cc3d - CMPX_INC
Increment between header word 7 values for CMP locations.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.

Help.Tip: Maximum CMP X grid location (header word 7).
Help.Text:
cc3d - CMPX_LAST
Maximum CMP X grid location (header word 7).
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real
 
 If both CMPX_LAST and CMPX_TOT are specified, CMPX_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Total number of CMP X grid locations (header word 7).
Help.Text:
cc3d - CMPX_TOT
Total number of CMP X grid locations (header word 7).
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int
 
 If both CMPX_LAST and CMPX_TOT are specified, CMPX_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Number of CMPs to composite in the CMP Y grid direction.
Help.Text:
cc3d - COMP_Y
Number of CMPs to composite in the CMP Y grid direction.
 
 Default = 5
 Allowed = int > 0
 
 Number of CMPs to composite in the CMP Y grid direction to form super-CMP
 base traces.

Help.Tip: Minimum CMP Y grid location (header word 8).
Help.Text:
cc3d - CMPY_INIT
Minimum CMP Y grid location (header word 8).
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Increment between header word 8 values for CMP locations.
Help.Text:
cc3d - CMPY_INC
Increment between header word 8 values for CMP locations.
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.

Help.Tip: Maximum CMP Y grid location (header word 8).
Help.Text:
cc3d - CMPY_LAST
Maximum CMP Y grid location (header word 8).
 
 Default =  1.0
 Allowed = real
 
 If both CMPY_LAST and CMPY_TOT are specified, CMPY_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Total number of CMP Y grid locations (header word 8).
Help.Text:
cc3d - CMPY_TOT
Total number of CMP Y grid locations (header word 8).
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int
 
 If both CMPY_LAST and CMPY_TOT are specified, CMPY_TOT takes precedence.

Help.Tip: Number of word of permanent storage to be used.
Help.Text:
cc3d - NSTORE
Number of word of permanent storage to be used.

Help.Tip: Number of word of temporary storage to be used.
Help.Text:
cc3d - NSCRATCH
Number of word of temporary storage to be used.

Help.Tip: Disk space (in megabytes) to be used.
Help.Text:
cc3d - DISK
Disk space (in megabytes) to be used.

Help.Tip: Number of processors in the job.
Help.Text:
cc3d - NCPUS
Number of processors in the job.

Help.Tip: Method to use for specifying trace windows.
Help.Text:
cc3d - WIN_OPT
Method to use for specifying trace windows.
 
 Default = MUTE
 Allowed = MUTE   (window defined by time measure from mute)
 Allowed = GRID   (window varies laterally, or same window everywhere)
 
 Segments of the input traces used in this process are defined by these
 windows.
 
 Option GRID specifies the trace windows by linked arrays of window top and
 window bottom values which may vary lateraly (spatially) over arbitrarily
 chosen coordinates.
 
 Option MUTE specifies the trace windows by specifying the time from the
 mute time to the top of the window, and the length of the window.
 
 Some processes might disable the MUTE option if it is not appropriate
 for that process.  In this case, the GRID option will be the default
 and only option.

Help.Tip: Time at top of window = mute time + WIN_TIM_ADD.
Help.Text:
cc3d - WIN_TIM_ADD
Time at top of window = mute time + WIN_TIM_ADD.
 
 Default = 0.0.
 Allowed = real value >= 0.0.
 Used only if WIN_OPT = MUTE.

Help.Tip: Time at bottom of window = time at top of window + WIN_TIM_LEN.
Help.Text:
cc3d - WIN_TIM_LEN
Time at bottom of window = time at top of window + WIN_TIM_LEN.
 
 Default = 1.0.
 Allowed = real value >= 0.0.
 Used only if WIN_OPT = MUTE.

Help.Tip: Header word designating window coordinate X.
Help.Text:
cc3d - WIN_HDR_X
Header word designating window coordinate X.
 
 Default = 7
 Allowed = any value from 1 through NWIH.
 Used only if WIN_OPT = GRID.
 
 Header word containing coordinate X to use for specifying spatially varying
 windows.

Help.Tip: Header word designating window coordinate Y.
Help.Text:
cc3d - WIN_HDR_Y
Header word designating window coordinate Y.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = any value from 1 through NWIH.
 Used only if WIN_OPT = GRID.
 
 Header word containing coordinate Y to use for specifying spatially varying
 windows.

Help.Tip: Array of coord X values for specifying spatially varying windows.
Help.Text:
cc3d - WIN_COOR_X
Array of coord X values for specifying spatially varying windows.
 
 Default = 0.0 (one location).
 Allowed = up to any number of locations specified by WIN_HDR_X values.
 Used only if WIN_OPT = GRID.
 
 The (WIN_COOR_X,WIN_COOR_Y) window locations must be on a rectangular grid,
 but not necessarily of regular spacing in either coordinate.  Therefore the
 total number of window locations must be the product of the number of
 separate WIN_COOR_X and WIN_COOR_Y locations.
 
 If only one X coordinate is specified, its value is irrelevant.

Help.Tip: Array of coord Y values for specifying spatially varying windows.
Help.Text:
cc3d - WIN_COOR_Y
Array of coord Y values for specifying spatially varying windows.
 
 Default = 0.0 (one location).
 Allowed = up to any number of locations specified by WIN_HDR_Y values.
 Used only if WIN_OPT = GRID.
 
 The (WIN_COOR_X,WIN_COOR_Y) window locations must be on a rectangular grid,
 but not necessarily of regular spacing in either coordinate.  Therefore the
 total number of window locations must be the product of the number of
 separate WIN_COOR_X and WIN_COOR_Y locations.
 
 If only one Y coordinate is specified, its value is irrelevant.
 For 2D data, only one Y coordinate should be specified.

Help.Tip: Array of window top times (in seconds).
Help.Text:
cc3d - WIN_TIM_BEG
Array of window top times (in seconds).
 
 Default = top of trace (TSTRT) (one window).
 Allowed = any number of values >= top of trace.
 Used only if WIN_OPT = GRID.
 
 This window is spatially varying as given at the (WIN_COOR_X,WIN_COOR_Y)
 locations.  The window is interpolated between the specified coordinates,
 and extrapolated unchanged outside of the grid of coordinates.

Help.Tip: Array of window bottom times (in seconds).
Help.Text:
cc3d - WIN_TIM_END
Array of window bottom times (in seconds).
 
 Default = bottom of trace (TSTRT+(NDPT-1)*DT) (one window).
 Allowed = any number of values > WIN_TIM_BEG and <= bottom of trace.
 Used only if WIN_OPT = GRID.
 
 This window is spatially varying as given at the (WIN_COOR_X,WIN_COOR_Y)
 locations.  The window is interpolated between the specified coordinates,
 and extrapolated unchanged outside of the grid of coordinates.

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
cc3d - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
Help.Text:
cc3d - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
Help.Text:
cc3d - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
Help.Text:
cc3d - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
cc3d - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
Help.Text:
cc3d - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
Help.Text:
cc3d - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to any chosen process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
Help.Text:
cc3d - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the next process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
Help.Text:
cc3d - PROJECTDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as Project Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of Project Defaults for a project.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
Help.Text:
cc3d - USERDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as User Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of User Defaults for a userid.

Help.Tip: Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
Help.Text:
cc3d - HELP
Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The Help Window allows access to three kinds of help:  Parameter Help, CPS
 Process Help and Application (CFE) Help.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         C P S   P R O C E S S
 
 Name       : CC3D
 Category   : statics
 Written    : 1996-05-25   by: Greg Lazear
 Revised    : 2006-09-18   by: D. Glover
 Maturity   : production
 Purpose    : 3D composite correlation statics.
 Portability: No known limitations.
 Parallel   : Yes.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          GENERAL DESCRIPTION
 
 CC3D is a surface consistent residual statics process that uses a generalized
 composite and correlate algorithm to estimate static shifts.  A detailed
 description of the CC3D algorithm is found in the Algorithm Description for
 Developers section.  A simplified version follows.
 
       1.  Traces are sorted into super-CMPs, each consisting of COMP_X *
       COMP_Y actual CMPs.  Loop over steps 2 - 4 for each super-CMP.
 
       2.  Apply previously derived shifts and composite traces to: super-CMP
       stacks and partial stacks (common source, common receiver, common CMP
       and common offset), with number of types of partial stacks determined
       by TERMS.  The common source stacked trace, common receiver stacked
       trace, etc., constitute statistical expectations of those individual
       gathers.
 
       3.  Correlate each partial stack against the super-CMP stack (with the
       partial stack removed) and pick the correlations to obtain an initial
       IMS-like estimate of the static for that term.
 
       4.  Stack the correlations with other correlations of the same term and
       sum the IMS-like shifts into an average for each term.
 
       5.  Pick the stacked correlations to get a FISH-like static estimate,
       combine this estimate with the IMS-like estimate, weighed according
       to the WEIGHT parameter, and add the statics estimates of this
       iteration to those of the previous iterations.
 
       6.  Iterate steps 2 - 5 NUM_ITER times.
 
       7.  Print results in the .rpt file, save statics files and optionally
       write the final stacked correlations to bytefiles.
 
 
 Source and Receiver Locations
 
 Source locations are designated by header words HDR_SX and HDR_SY;
 receiver locations are designated by header words HDR_RX and HDR_RY.
 These header words define a source grid and a receiver grid which determine
 the size of the source and receiver statics files.  Traces that fall outside
 either the source or the receiver grid will be dropped.
 
 The header words SX_INC, SY_INC, RX_INC, and RY_INC specify increments of the
 source and receiver headers for occupied source and receiver locations.  Each
 actual source and receiver location found in trace headers will be binned
 into the nearest location specified by these parameters for purposes of
 calculating statics.
 
 This index saves memory when the grid is only sparsely occupied by sources or
 receivers.
 
 
 CMP Locations and Super-CMPs
 
 CMP locations are designated by header words 7 and 8 which are the stack-bin
 grid coordinates.  Traces are dropped if they fall outside of this grid.
 This grid is extended slightly, if necessary, to make whole super-bins
 of COMP_X and COMP_Y CMPs.  Traces are dropped if the fold in a super-bin
 exceeds FOLD_MAX * COMP_X * COMP_Y traces.
 
 The COMP_X and COMP_Y parameters are in "counting" units, meaning a value
 of seven will composite seven CMPs, independent of their grid increments. Thus
 CMPs with consecutive header 7 values of (120, 120.5, 121, 121.5, 122) would
 be composited when COMP_X=5, even though their range in header word 7 units
 is 2.
 
 
 Disk Allocation
 
 This program is an all-trace process, and uses the CMP grid specification and
 FOLD_MAX to allocate disk space for the traces.  It is important not to make
 FOLD_MAX unnecessarily large, because this could waste a lot of disk space.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                            ADVICE FOR USERS
 
 
 Choice of Coordinates
 
 CMP locations are designated by the CMP grid coordinates (header words 7 and
 8).  Users must choose header words to designate source and receiver
 locations as follows:
 
 Source Coordinate Options     Source Header Words
 
       Shot Profile Number           9
       Sequential Ground Position   46
       Shotpoint and Line Number    29 and 26
       Grid Coordinates             33 and 34
 
 Receiver Coordinate Options   Receiver Header Words
 
       Sequential Ground Position   47
       Shotpoint and Line Number    28 and 27
       Grid Coordinates             35 and 36
 
 Source and receiver coordinate choices are independent of each other.
 
 
 Coordinate Recommendations
 
 Normally, if sequential ground position header words have been set in the
 input dataset, the ground position is the best choice for source and receiver
 coordinates since static and byte files are smaller and static determination
 may be more acurate.  However, if there is more than one source pop per
 source location, then shot profile number should be used for the source
 coordinate.
 
 If sequential ground position header words have not been set in the input
 dataset and the datset is relatively small then shotpoint or line number
 coordinates may be the next best choice.  Grid coodinates are another
 possible choice with these drawbacks:
 
       1.  Grid coordinates may not be densely populated making internal
       calculations slower, disk use higher and static and byte files larger.
 
       2.  Statics are calculated only at regular grid intersections.  If
       sources and receivers are not always located exactly on the
       intersections then applying the statics files will probably produce
       somewhat inaccurate results.
 
 Normally, grid coordinates are not a good choice for large datasets
 because this usually causes the static files to be extremely large and
 mostly filled with nils.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                        SUMMARY OF PARAMETERS
 
 Correlation window parameters:   Standard laterally varying time window
                                  parameters in the LATWIN primitive.
 
 File output parameters:          PATH_SRC, PATH_REC,
 File output parameters:          HDR_SRC, HDR_REC,
                                  CORR_FILES, NO_DEAD
 
 Printing parameters:             OPT_PRINT
 
 Static solution parameters:      MAX_STATIC, NUM_ITER, WEIGHT, TERMS,
                                  PWR_CC, TAPER, UPDATE, OFF_WID
 
 Source ground position ranges:   HDR_SX, SX_INIT, SX_INC, SX_LAST, SX_TOT
                                  HDR_SY, SY_INIT, SY_INC, SY_LAST, SY_TOT
 
 Receiver ground position ranges: HDR_RX, RX_INIT, RX_INC, RX_LAST, RX_TOT
                                  HDR_RY, RY_INIT, RY_INC, RY_LAST, RY_TOT
 
 CMP parameters:           COMP_X, CMPX_INIT, CMPX_INC, CMPX_LAST, CMPX_TOT
                           COMP_Y, CMPY_INIT, CMPY_INC, CMPY_LAST, CMPY_TOT
                           FOLD_MAX
